HDG.FS.content: Heraclitus’ Fragment 72 names humans and their “departure from being (Abkommen vom Sein)” (cf. Being and Time), designates a fall upon/away/from beings (Verfall oder Ab-fall [an das Seinde]) > this fall belongs to Difference (Unterschied) btwn Being/beings, so that Fall of Man sets aside [obscures] this difference > for Heraclitus, the foreign depart from difference [not as antagonistically (feindlich) disposed toward foreign (Fremden) as Plato]

HDG.FS.content: Plato names eidōlon as mē on (“un-being”), distinguishes from ouk on, sheer non-being [cf. pp. 39, 42] > eidōlon also distinguished from eidos, that which shows itself, what one sees > but one can’t reach eidos w/out eidōlon, table obscured by wood of which it’s made > Aristotle brings Ideas back to earth, eidos becomes morphē of a tode ti in motion/rest: kinēsis (and for Aristotle all moves) defined as energeai (entelecheia), thus energeia highest determination of being

HDG.FS.content: how does Platonic idea (eidos) correspond to what Greeks named presence, ousia, the most extreme excess? for Plato, to change, to alter oneself (sich ändern): abwesen (to absence)—idea as pure presence, never absencing, self-maintaining-making-present, presencing presence (anwesende Anwesenheit) as what’s there in excess, ontos on (Nietzsche had strong sense of this, Twilight of…)

HDG.DL.content: explanation (Erläuterung) of hermeneutics may issue (versteht) in a discussion (Erörterung) [Trakl essay] > hermenuein to hermeneus to Hermes (playful thought more compelling than rigor of sense): divine messenger, brings message of destiny (Botschaft des Geschickes) > hermeneuein: explanation that brings tidings (Kunde), can listen to a message > Plato’s Ion: poets “are interpreters (hermenes) of gods” > hermeneutics not just interpretation but the bearing (das Bringen) of message/tidings

HDG.LP.content: since Plato, soul suprasensuous (Übersinnlichen), if it appears in sensible world, does so as a castaway (verschlagen) > on Earth, soul doesn’t have the right cast (rechten Schlag), doesn’t belong, is something strange (ein Fremdes) [body is soul’s prison]

HDG.EC.content: Nietzsche interpreted morality, the Platonic-Christian ethical doctrine, & its later secularized forms (rational Ethics of Enlightenment/socialism), as appearances (Erscheinungen) of will to power > Nietzsche didn’t realize that a will to power “beyond good & evil,” as realm of pure will to power, remains only counter-world (Gegenwelt) to Platonism > Nietzsche’s doctrine of “discipline and breeding (Zucht und Züchtung)” is extreme affirmation of morality > if will is evil, will to power is least of all beyond evil
